issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Animal with two attributes (name: String and age: int) and a constructor Animal(String, int) (problem_statement.md lines 26-31). However, both the provided template Main and the solution repository use/expect single-argument constructors for concrete animals (e.g., Seal("Clarabelle") in template Main) and the solution's Animal class only defines a single-argument constructor Animal(String) and no age attribute. This mismatch between the UML/specified constructor and the actual constructors/attributes in template and solution is structural: students reading the UML may implement Animal and concrete animals with (String, int) constructors and an age field, while the template usage and reference solution use only name. This can confuse students about which attributes and constructor signatures they must implement and may lead to failing tests or friction when following the provided Main examples.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the specification, template, and solution consistent. Either (A) update the problem UML and any textual references to remove the age attribute and the two-argument Animal constructor (keeping a single-argument constructor that initializes name only), or (B) update the template Main, template stubs, and the solution to include the age attribute and two-argument constructors for Animal and all concrete animals (and add corresponding getters/setters). Ensure the example usage in Main and the instructions match the chosen design.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Animal with two attributes (name: String and age: int) and a constructor Animal(String, int) (problem_statement.md lines 26-31). However, both the template usage (template Main.java uses Seal("Clarabelle"), Pig("Doodle"), Goat("Buttinsky") — single String argument; template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Main.java lines 9-11) and the solution implementation define Animal and all concrete animals with a single-String constructor and no age attribute (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Animal.java uses Animal(String) and has only a name field; see solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Animal.java lines 3-8). This creates a mismatch between the problem UML and the provided/expected code: students reading the UML may attempt to implement an age field and two-argument constructors, while the template/example usage and solution expect single-argument constructors. The inconsistency can cause confusion about required attributes and constructor signatures.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor/attribute expectations consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement UML to remove the age:int attribute and change the UML constructor to Animal(String) (so it matches the template usage and solution), or (B) update the template and solution to include the age field and two-argument constructors (Animal(String, int)) and adjust all subclass constructors and example usages (Main.java) accordingly. Prefer (A) if the course examples and tests expect only a name parameter.
